newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh struggles to save forest from gas fire.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh struggles to save forest from gas fire.

text.p: Workers struggled on Tuesday to save a rich timber forest in northeast Bangladesh from a raging fire that engulfed a natural gas field at the weekend.
Fire-fighting experts from Singapore arrived to assess the blaze at the Mugrachhara gas field, in the heart of the country's tea-growing Moulavi Bazar district.

Energy Ministry officials said more experts and equipment were expected soon from the U.S. headquarters of Occidental Petroleum Corp, which was drilling at the field when a rig hit trapped gas on Sunday and ignited the blaze.
"The large, thick forest surrounding the fire site is under serious threat," Badrul Anam, Assistant Conservationist from the Sylhet Forest told Reuters.
"We are worried what would happen in the scorching summer heat if a big wind comes up -- the flames are drying leaves and branches and can spark fire any time. It will be a disaster then," he said.
The fire, which Occidental executives say could burn for weeks, has already destroyed parts of two nearby tea gardens and plantations belonging to tribal Khasia villagers.

Workers were trying to make a fireline by cutting rows of trees around the blazing well, but Anam said there were no resources to tackle a large forest fire. The 10,000-acre reserve forest surrounding the field is rich with timber planted since the early 1920s.
Mohammad Atiqul Azam, a divisional forest officer in Sylhet, said a preliminary damage assessment would be ready in two days.

"We don't know what the (biological) impact will be as it depends how long the fire will rage. But as of now we are fearing major damage... I am afraid it may take many years for the area to recover."

Forest workers were unable to approach the fire because of flames leaping 300-to-500 feet (100-to-150 metres) into the air. Four Bangladeshis were hurt in the blaze and nearby railway tracks also caught fire.
Police have surrounded the area, allowing only experts and officials near the fire.
Rafiq Ahmed, a forest guard who was on a routine patrol at the time of the accident, said he had wondered whether the world was ending.

"I suddenly heard a big sound like a roaring railway engine and saw the forest had been lit by a huge fire. Workers at the rig were running into the jungle for (their) life. I too rushed back to my jungle camp and immediately began running away," he said.
Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was due to visit the fire site on Tuesday, her aides said.
